paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination increase tumor sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade, and are the findings consistent in both murine models and retrospective human ICI-treated patients?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Murine efficacy studies testing intratumoral mRNA vaccination combined with anti-PD-L1 in multiple tumor models.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched murine controls receiving vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle treatment for comparison against sensitization outcomes.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors, analyzed retrospectively by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective cohort previously vaccinated with a SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine before/around ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Comparison group of metastatic patients without documented SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination for survival and clinical outcome contrasts.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all settings.
